org.ggp.base.player.gamer.statemachine.sample

Class SampleSearchLightGamer

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.ggp.base.player.gamer.Gamer
      • org.ggp.base.player.gamer.statemachine.StateMachineGamer
        • org.ggp.base.player.gamer.statemachine.sample.SampleSearchLightGamer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Subject

    public final class SampleSearchLightGamer
extends StateMachineGamer
    SampleSearchLightGamer is a simple state-machine-based Gamer. It will, to the best of its ability, never pick a move which will give its opponent a possible one-move win. It will also spend up to two seconds looking for one-move wins it can take. This makes it slightly more challenging than the RandomGamer, while still playing reasonably fast. Essentially, it has a one-move search-light that it shines out, allowing it to avoid moves that are immediately terrible, and also choose moves that are immediately excellent. This approach implicitly assumes that it is playing an alternating-play game, which is not always true. It will play simultaneous-action games less well. It also assumes that it is playing a zero-sum game, where its opponent will always force it to lose if given that option. This player is fairly good at games like Tic-Tac-Toe, Knight Fight, and Connect Four. This player is pretty terrible at most games.
    Author:
    Sam Schreiber

      • stateMachineSelectMove

        public Move stateMachineSelectMove(long timeout)
                            throws TransitionDefinitionException,
                                   MoveDefinitionException,
                                   GoalDefinitionException
        Employs a simple sample "Search Light" algorithm. First selects a default legal move. It then iterates through all of the legal moves in random order, updating the current move selection using the following criteria.
        1. If a move produces a 1 step victory (given a random joint action) select it
        2. If a move produces a 1 step loss avoid it
        3. If a move allows a 2 step forced loss avoid it
        4. Otherwise select the move
        Specified by:
        stateMachineSelectMove in class StateMachineGamer
        Parameters:
        timeout - time in milliseconds since the era when this function must return
        Returns:
        Move - the move selected by the player
        Throws:
        TransitionDefinitionException
        MoveDefinitionException
        GoalDefinitionException
